You claim to have controlled a Class 4 Paradox with willpower, Bodhi. That is not science; it is delusion. The Ward Lattice was already destabilized by the Lunar transit. Your 'miracle' nearly triggered a cascade failure across the entire eastern seaboard. You didn't just risk yourself. You risked everyone." I nod, the humor draining out of my posture. "I know the math, Saanvi. But the math doesn't scream when it bleeds out." A few students in the upper mezzanine—allowed to observe for pedagogical value—stifle laughs before tutors glare them silent.Virelia raps a gavel of moon‑silver. The sound is soft yet final, like a guillotine cushioned with velvet. "Explain your spellwork. In detail." I unspool it. How Standard Regeneration forces cellular genesis forward—too slow for a pulmo‑hemorrhagic collapse. How Time Reversal bends causality but drags surrounding reality like a toddler’s blanket, risking wide‑area paradox. How both require umpteen practitioners chanting in key while the patient’s life bleeds out a metronome. My method? Entropy drag. "You treat injuries as open thermodynamic systems," I say, pacing within my hex‑radius. "Force the wound state to trade entropy with the Null Field. Body moves toward lower‑entropy configuration—aka healthy—while the field uptakes the disorder. The trick is establishing a fuse." Cleon sneers. "Spare us the poetry, Mr. Rao. The actuarial tables don't care about your 'tricks'. The Null Field collapsed twenty‑three seconds post‑procedure." "Because I was the fuse, Cleon. If the field collapsed, it would have imploded me, not the ward. I did the math. I just didn't factor in your comfort levels. Zero civilian casualties, unless you count my career. But that was terminal anyway." Astell turns plum. "Irrelevant. You circumvented every safety protocol to flaunt your—" "—to save a kid abandoned by protocol," I cut in. My voice echoes, riding the chamber’s perfect acoustics. "Had I waited for your four‑thaumiphysician choir, she’d be a chalk outline." Murmurs bubble. Virelia raises her hand and the room stills. "Intent does not absolve recklessness. Doctrine exists to harness power for the common good." I laugh, short and crooked. "Doctrine exists to gatekeep the divine. If good were common we wouldn’t price it by the hour." A sub‑clerk hovers a scroll‑slab toward me. Case histories flicker: Alcester v. The Collective, Van‑Luik Reversal Incident, each a cautionary tale of lone mages who cooked themselves alive attempting entropy inversion. My favorite bedtime stories.Virelia taps the scroll. "These tragedies prove why quorum is mandatory." "They prove why the quorum of cowards is lethal," I reply. "Every one of those med‑teams refused to act until they formed a committee. People died waiting for a vote that never closed." Saanvi’s eyes flutter shut. She’s seen the same corpses. Cleon arches a brow, scenting weakness in his colleague. "Elder Belgaran, perhaps you’d like to remind the defendant of the stable miracles ratio?" She exhales. "Three practitioners minimize entropy feedback by distributing metabolic cost across synced circulatory matrices—" "—Unless one practitioner is me," I interrupt. "My vitals remain within tolerance post‑spell." I hold out my hands, palms up. "No necrotic bloom. No fissured aura. Check the telemetry." A holographic panel materializes mid‑air, courtesy of the Regulator medic who processed me. My biosign curves glide across in neat sine waves. Heart rate elevated but steady; entropy saturation at 62%—ugly but survivable.Saanvi frowns at the data, torn between disbelief and grudging respect. Cleon overrides. "Even if you withstood it, you jeopardized the ward lattice. We had to divert power from neonatal stasis rooms to reinforce the grid. Three infants nearly de-synced because you wanted to play god with a gunshot wound." I bite back a retort about billable priorities. Instead I pivot. "The patient lives." The statement hangs like incense. No one responds. Truth rarely needs allies; it just needs air.A hush falls so complete I swear I hear dust motes pirouette. In that pause my gaze drifts upward, past suppression discs, to stained‑glass oculi depicting The First Miracle: a robed figure splitting darkness with light. I wonder what tribunal he faced afterward.Heat stings behind my eyes—unexpected, unwelcome. I channel it into words. "My mother died in a ward ten meters from here," I say softly. "Tumor the size of regret in her frontal lobe. Academy surgeons called it economically non‑viable to attempt Class III excision. You signed that letter, Arch‑Elder." Virelia blinks once, the only crack in her alabaster mask. "You conflate policy with—" "I conflate policy with hypocrisy." The admission tastes like rust. "So when a girl rolled into that alley with her lungs sautéed, I saw my mother’s ghost telling me to break the rules that broke her." No one meets my eyes. Good. Let guilt crowd their retinas.Elder Technocrat Imir Solvan, silent until now, adjusts his neural halo—thin ring of light mapping mind to archive. "Mr. Rao, your incantation contained an anomalous glyphic sub-routine: ThRun-kel Tuu Vaar'lenna. Translation lost to public lexicons. Where did you obtain it?" Ah, there it is—the real hunt. "My grandmother’s prayer book," I lie smoothly. "A bedtime benediction for unruly weather. Old family superstition." The lie settles heavy in my gut. I’m not just hiding a technique; I’m hiding Her. If they knew Saint Nalini was dabbling in Atavistic Entropy—messing with forces that could unzip the city—her statue in the atrium would be rubble by morning.Imir’s halo stutters. He knows I’m bluffing. The ring of light abruptly contracts, tightening around his temples like a vice, casting a targeting reticle over his left eye. He leans forward, the light burning hot enough to smell like ozone. He knows. But proving it would require a deep-dive scan that overrides tribunal protocol. He slowly relaxes the halo, accepting the convenient fiction, but the threat remains scorched into the air. Better a reckless student than a corrupted legend.Virelia signals the dais. A translucent veil descends, muting their voices while they deliberate. From my position I watch their silhouettes mime outrage, concern, self‑preservation—an interpretive dance of bureaucracy. It hits me then, watching them argue not about if I should be expelled, but how. They aren't expelling me because I failed. They're expelling me because I worked. Because I used "impossible" magic to fix a problem their perfect System declared unsolvable. If I can rewrite entropy without their permission, what else can I do? I am a variable they cannot isolate, an irregularity in their perfect equation.Above, suppression discs slow, as if the room itself holds its breath.Minutes stretch origami-long. Students whisper; quills scratch; somewhere a regulator pops gum. I roll my shoulders. The hex-chain loosens a millimeter—enough to remind me entropy favors change. I could snap it, maybe. Melt through the suppression grid, sprint for the corridor. But that would undermine the point: the guilty should not need to run.The veil rises.Virelia stands, gavel poised but not yet struck. "The Council finds the defendant—" A hush funnels every heartbeat into my ears. I see Saanvi’s lips tremble, Cleon’s nostrils flare, Imir’s halo spin. "—in violation of Articles 7, 12, and 19. Sentencing to be pronounced following procedural ratification by the Internal Safety Review Board at oh‑six‑hundred." So they kick the can to sunrise. Bureaucracy’s favorite alarm clock. Cleon adds, "In the interim, you remain in custody under probationary suspension."Regulators move to escort me. I smirk. "Guess I’m trending." Before they guide me out, Saanvi catches my eye. She looks at the empty seat beside me—where my mother would have sat—then back to me. It's not confusion in her face; it's the grief of watching potential incinerate itself. She mouths a single word: why? I tap my chest twice—heartbeat, hope—and let the question hang unanswered. She thinks I threw it all away. She doesn't understand that I'm the only one keeping the inheritance safe. "I'll also accept 'Your Majesty' or 'Papa' if the first one feels too formal," I mutter under my breath, but the joke is ash in my mouth. It lands with a dull thud, protecting nothing. As the doors seal behind me, the last thing I see is Virelia polishing her gavel like a trophy hunter buffing ivory.The corridor greets me again, colder now. I breathe in recycled air heavy with cleansing aether and taste tomorrow’s judgment. Somewhere, the healed girl inhales too—lungs unscarred because I dared entropy to a duel. No council verdict can rewrite that equation. I saved her.The thought crystallizes, sharp as the sigil drying on my palm. My resolve anneals in the furnace of official disdain. If the system thinks suspension will temper me, it misunderstands metallurgy: some alloys harden under fire.I let the Regulators lead me toward holding—but my shadow stretches ahead, carving a path toward whatever rebellion waits at dawn. [AUDIO FRAGMENT: FILE_CORRUPT_08 // SOURCE: VIRAL_FEED] People love to act like all mages are created equal - just a bunch of robe-wearing wand-wavers doing cool hand signs and quoting Latin. But the truth? The magical world is as stratified, smug, and stupidly hierarchical as everything else. Doesn’t matter how many spells you know or how many times you’ve saved someone’s life - your title says more about your bank account than your talent. Everyone wants to be a Sorcerer. No one wants to be a Cleric. Then there are five types of magic so far above our paygrade, they get capital letters: Creation, Spacetime, Truth, all that divine jazz. No one has seen those for the better part of 2 millennia. We call them the Five Divinities, because calling them "completely inaccessible plot devices" didn’t test well with the clergy. Supposedly, they were once wielded by god-tier magi who could rewrite existence, undo causality, and speak lies so true they became fact. These days? They’re more myth than method - classified, forbidden, or just plain extinct. But hey, if you ever meet someone who can conjure uranium or rewind time, run. Or bow. Maybe both. So let’s break it down: *Sorcerers: Born with it. Magical bloodlines. Intuitive and arrogant.* *Wizards: Learned it. Walk encyclopedias. Paranoid control freaks.* *Warlocks: Borrowed it. Made a deal. Definitely overcompensating.* *Druids: Channel it. Tree huggers with superiority complexes.* *Clerics: Heal it. Soul surgeons who think band-aids are for cowards.* I’m a Cleric. Which is a fancy way of saying I went to med school for magic and came out with a PhD in patching up people dumb enough to set themselves on fire. My mom’s a Sorceress. Healing runs in our family - not power, just responsibility. You think ER docs have it hard? Try doing trauma surgery with your soul. Magic doesn’t just fix the body. It forces it back into shape. And every time we do it, a little piece of us goes missing. You'd think that would earn me some respect. Maybe money. Some pity at least. Nah. I sit at the bottom of the magical caste system, somewhere between "unpaid intern" and "miracle janitor." Nobody wants to talk about the politics of magic, but it’s everywhere. Thaumaturgy is treated like a hard science because it sounds like math. Theurgy gets funding because it invokes gods. Spellcasting? That’s the "Just Add Fireball" crowd. Meanwhile, my field - Healing Magic - is seen as passive, feminine, imprecise. Never mind the fact that I’m rewiring souls and stitching minds together with my bare aura. That doesn’t make headlines. It just makes survivors. But sure, let's keep pretending that magical academia isn’t shaped by the same classist, racist, colonial rot as everything else. The head elder’s gavel isn’t made of wood. It’s wrenched from something older—petrified dragon‑bone inlaid with antimony runes that glint like collapsed stars. When it descends, the crack isn’t sound; it’s pressure, a micro‑quake shivering air, marrow, memory. Wards stitched into the vaulted ceiling flare, swallowing the vibration before it can bruise the gold‑lined frescoes. Justice must never dent the décor. "By unanimous decree," intones Elder Virelia, voice smoothed by centuries of acceptable outrage, "Bodhisunya Rao is hereby placed on indefinite suspension pending further review. Effective immediately. All associated privileges, peripherals, and accreditations are rescinded. Assets held by the Academy Bank are frozen to offset ward damages." Indefinite. The syllables hit like wet cement—slow, heavy, irreversible once set. I catalogue the council faces out of spite: Virelia’s alabaster serenity; Cleon's twitching left eye (expensive nerve tonic, ironically); Saanvi's fingers fussing with an invisible ledger only she can see, trying her hardest not to meet my eyeline. Not one of them looks relieved. No, relief would imply risk, empathy, shared consequence. What I register gleaming behind their polite masks is simpler: administrative closure.Somewhere beyond the dais, the spectral scribe‑orb hovers, whirring as it etches the ruling into transmutable crystal. A new entry for the Academy archives, filed between Dormitory Fire, 241 AE and Alchemical Plague Inquiry, 243 AE. My name will glow there in neat rune‑font, a cautionary subheading: Violation: Unauthorized Miracle‑work, Null‑Field Causality Reversal. "Do you understand the council’s verdict?" Cleon asks, ritual words echoing off pillars the width of ancestral guilt. My tongue could choose tact—or it could pick the lock on their composure. I flex broken knuckles and decide I’m done with tact. "Crystal," I answer, smiling just wide enough to weaponize a molar‑chip. "Though given the Academy’s fondness for crystal, maybe you should etch it on my forehead. Easier for the next patrol to scan." Gasps ripple from the mezzanine where junior archivists cluster like flightless ravens. One drops a rune‑slate; it clatters, the noise swallowed by an acoustic damping field quicker than shame. Cleon’s eyelids shutter half‑mast—a palace guard ignoring a jester’s stool joke—and he pivots to the procedural finale. "Place your left hand upon the Suppression Sigil." A podium rises from the marble dais, silent as guilt, revealing a recessed plate of cold electrum inscribed with a living ward. Filaments writhe across its surface, searching for a pulse to devour. I plant my hand without ceremony. The sigil flares, scans, condemns.A terse chime. Then the systematic unthreading begins.My coat—a battered grey long‑line, regulation cut but riddled with illicit stitch‑sigils—reacts first. The chest pocket, once proud with a triad of badges, spasms like flesh meeting acid.click‑tchhh— The Clerical Adept Crest pops loose, detaches, and hovers a heartbeat before drifting toward the podium’s receiving halo. The Medical Discipline Glyph follows, its serpent‑and‑chalice icon shedding cobalt sparks as authorization sigils erase themselves mid‑air. Last is the Field Supplicant Seal, earned during a charity plague ward two winters ago; it trembles, reluctant, then rips itself free, tearing a neat square of fabric as it goes.Three emblems spin in lazy orbit above the Suppression Sigil, cooling slag to my smolder. They dissolve into light—the Academy reclaiming invested thaumic capital as efficiently as a loan shark cracking kneecaps for interest.The theft leaves phantom weight on my chest, like bandages torn from a half-healed burn. It hurts—a sharp, tearing deeper than skin. I’m lighter, yes—but raw, nerves open to the chill exhaled by marble saints perched around the rotunda. I inhale that cold, let it plate the ache in iron, and meet Cleon’s gaze. "Satisfied? Or do you need my spine too?" No reply. But I see a twitch—a fractional tightening near his brow as the chamber wards record my insolence. Let them. Every syllable is another splinter under their lacquer‑polished ethics.The session adjourns. Elders rise in synchronized exhaustion, a murmuration of ivory robes rustling like dry parchment. They descend side aisles to private lifts, refusing to pass me directly—as if suspension is contagious demon‑pox.Court recorders deactivate scry‑orbs and collapse quill stands. Spectators file out, heads bowed, boots silent on ward‑hushed stone. Some cast sideways pity‑glances; others look right through me, calibrating optics for an inconvenient ghost. I don’t flinch until I catch the hazel stare of Fenya Sokolov—second‑year Rune Pathologist, debate partner, friend in better hours. She holds my gaze a full two seconds, lips parted with words she’ll never risk. Then she pivots, cloak flaring like a coward’s white flag.Fine.For a moment the chamber empties, the hush so complete I can hear my blood choreographing revenge between heartbeats. Then he appears. A boy no older than twelve slides from behind a pillar, clutching something in both fists. Regulation uniform two sizes too big, knees scabbed, eyes ringed in feverish gratitude. Recognition kicks in. The girl’s brother. His voice is a library whisper: "Mister Rao?" I drop to a squat, level with his terror. Up close I see dried blood in his hair—someone tried to clean him up and ran out of time. "That’s me," I say, trying not to sound like the cellblock reaper. "Your sister holding steady?" He nods enough to rattle bones. "They moved her to Intensive Miracle Ward. The doctors said… they said she shouldn’t be breathing, but she is. Because of you." I want to smile but the muscles misfire. He extends a crumpled scrap of paper—Academy prescription pad torn corner, ink smeared by sweat and hope. I unfold it: THANK YOU — scrawled in looped child letters. Beneath, a shaky glyph: a phoenix feather entwined with the null sign. The improvised rune for second chances.My throat closes. All the snark, all the polished cynicism, gone useless against this guerrilla gratitude. I tuck the note inside my sleeve where badges used to be. "Tell her she owes me for the—" The joke dissolves. I try again. "Tell her… I’m still on call. If she needs me." He swallows, salutes in sloppy imitation of arrival drills, and scurries toward public egress before regulators notice him. His footfalls fade, but the warmth he left stings hotter than ward‑burns.A new figure approaches: Superintendent Helene Draxis, steward of disciplinary facilities, reputation forged from tungsten and final notices. She carries a crystal tablet showing logistics: escort rotation, asset reclamation, restricted corridor clearance. Her gaze sweeps the room, verifying the emptiness before she addresses me. "Rao, you are to vacate Academy grounds within the hour. Dormitory access revoked. Library credentials purged. Per code 117-B you may retrieve personal effects under supervision. Formal sentencing will be ratified at 0600. Until then, you are an unperson." I stand, coat flapping ragged where badges used to anchor it. "Does per code 117‑B include a farewell parade? Balloons? Maybe a marching band in minor key?" She stares as if parsing a dialect she once knew and forgot on purpose. "Your humor is a waste of time." "This whole thing is a waste of time, look around you." I gesture at the deserted benches, the rune‑scarred podium still tasting my DNA. "Do we need an escort to the gate, or will the walls move for me?" "The walls," she says, monotone as a null field, "are not your concern. Two regulators will accompany you." She flicks her wrist; behind her, a pair of crimson‑armored sentries peel from shadow, wands holstered but hands tense. Regulators again. Full circle. Cosmic joke.Draxis turns to leave, stops, and without facing me asks, "Was it worth it?" There it is—the question everyone pretends is rhetorical. I check the sleeve pocket where fragile paper presses my pulse. "Every magicked‑up minute." She exhales through nostrils, either disdain or reluctant respect—I can’t read the signature. Then she walks. The regulators flank me.We exit through Processional Exit Hallway E, a rabbit warren designed more for ceremony than traffic efficiency: Corinthian columns, azurite mosaics depicting sanitized miracles, chandeliers forged from salvaged phoenix ash. Everything screams victory lap, but tonight the corridor is a morgue in holiday lights.My boots echo. The regulators’ boots refuse to—sound dampened by hushwards, because silence enforces dignity.Halfway down the passage a flock of first‑years waits, jittering. They part like water around an oil spill, avoiding eye contact. One whispers, "That’s him," another mutters, "Null-field butcher." The nickname ricochets inside my skull—brand new, already rusting. I keep walking.At the corridor’s midpoint stands a statue of Madame Rehka Lyra, the Academy’s patron saint of sanctioned resilience. Bronze robes flow in alchemical perpetuity. She cradles an hourglass; inside, infinitesimal stardust resets every sixty seconds—a reminder that time, like policy, can be bent but never broken. Someone has draped a white ribbon around her wrist, symbol of structural mercy. I snort. Even effigies get sympathy.A gust slides through hidden vents, fluttering my coat hem, stirring the still‑bleeding tear where badges were evicted. The fabric whispers against itself, almost shaping words.At the ornate arch marking the transition from tribunal wing to dormitory‑spine, my escorts halt. They confer silently—one projects a hologlyph verifying transfer; the other adjusts sonic cuffs clipped to his belt. A warded turnstile looms ahead, currently dormant but hungry. "Retrieve your belongings," the taller regulator says. He holds up a scanner. "We monitor. No unexpected artifacts." I nod, step through the turnstile. It lights up, scanning for contraband miracle residue. The brand on my wrist—a new sigil formed by the suppression spell—pulses, interacting with the gate. For a second I expect alarms, grapples, maybe a humiliating strip search. But the ward recognizes its own handiwork: asset neutralized. A green rune blinks. Passage granted.Dormitory corridor: dim, late, smelling of sweat, ink, and the last days of childhood. My doorplate has already rewritten itself from RAO, B. — CLERICAL TRACK to VACANT – TO BE ASSIGNED. Efficient.Inside, the room is smaller than I remember, but grief always expands interior dimensions. I shove textbooks, arcane notebooks, half‑finished null field equations into a travel satchel. The canvas strains; calculation shards poke through seams. On the nightstand: a holo‑photo of my mother mid‑laughter, pre‑illness, when magic was still bedtime myth. I hesitate, then slip the wafer behind the boy’s note—double‑layered talisman against institutional amnesia.At the closet, my reflection glints off a cracked mirror. Coat torn, eyes sunken, brand glowing sullen violet. The man staring out looks feral but awake. "Rules be damned," I whisper. The mirror doesn’t argue. Satchel slung, I return to the corridor where regulators wait like bored gargoyles. We march toward the exit logistics have mapped. Each step scatters the ghosts of conversations, friendships, lectures, debts. Hungry silence devours them before they settle.Finally, a T‑junction. Left leads to administration egress and the world beyond. Right leads deeper inside—to academic spires, relic halls, lecture theaters. My escorts steer left.But halfway through the pivot, I stop.Because from the depths of Corridor Delta a light flickers—old gaslamp alley glow, impossible inside this palace of sanctioned lumens. It beats like a pulse, a dare. And I remember: Ghost‑Lit Corridors wait. Vitrines. Statues. A private zero‑hour pilgrimage to mock saints and mourn badges. "I need the restroom," I say. The regulators exchange glances—regulation code allows biological breaks. One points left toward public washrooms. I point right. "These pipes," I lie, "don’t play nice with null field burns. There’s a med‑niche past the reliquary. Two minutes." They hesitate. Then the scanner beeps—flatline normal. They checked me for active magic and found nothing because I'm suppressing my own signature. Their overconfidence is their blind spot. I layer exhaustion across my shoulders, add a tremor to my hand. Permission granted with curt nods.I walk right. I don’t hurry—that would trigger pursuit. But inside, my pulse drumming a war cadence, narrative gravity pivots.Each step away from egress is a step toward something else—Ghost‑Lit Corridors, vitrines of legendary healers, the roaring silence of icons who saved like I did but with permission slips. My destination unfurls ahead: a shadowed artery no longer patrolled at classroom hours.Behind me, regulators remain silhouettes at the edge of ward light, giving the illusion of trust. Good. They don’t know I’m already forging a new badge from resolve and spite.At the mouth of the reliquary hall I pause. I take the crumpled note from my sleeve, feel its soft rebellion whisper live. Tuck it near my heart. Straighten coat torn open for new mythologies.I step forward, into gloom lit by relic glow, leaving suspension verdicts to fossilize behind me. They took my badges. They couldn't take the hands that earned them. I kept those, if not the dignity of title or station. If I left, I left with clean hands in my pockets and my gaze level with theirs.

item.title: chapter-02-draft
item.description: [AUDIO FRAGMENT: FILE_CORRUPT_04 // SOURCE: VIRAL_FEED] ...look, maybe I should back up. Definitions matter. The old guard wants you to think Magic is some mystical favor from the Gods. Screw that. By-and-large, the magical world is wrapped up in the same veneer of Civility as the Mundane. And to the detriment of all involved, is entrenched in the same level of bureaucracy, hypocrisy, and corruption. But I digress! ...where was I? Right. "Magic." Wrong. Magic follows laws. Conservation, Entropy, Flux, Displacement. It has principles just like physics. It’s just... messier. Less Newton, more Schrödinger. Magic is a science, like anything else. Understand this: everything that exists in our reality, exists within the confines of the Rules of Reality. Just because something does not fit into our understanding of the world, does not mean it violates it. Some time in the 40s, a few magically inclined physicists came to a conclusion that would have turned the World on its head, if the information wasn't surpressed. At its core, Magic is the fifth fundamental force of the universe. Right up there with gravity and whatever it is that keeps your atoms from vibing out of existence. Except this one has an on-again/off-again relationship with order and loves loopholes. There’s a whole ass list of magical laws. Thermodynamic knockoffs. Newtonian reboots. Gauss with jazz hands. We call ‘em the 12 Laws of Thaumaturgy. They matter - but only if you plan on living through spellcasting. Magic displaces reality. Literally. It creates a void where the laws of physics collapse and new rules can take over. Think of it as reality having a panic attack. Physics takes five, and Magic strolls in with a Venti double espresso and a grudge. If reality were a bathtub, Magic is your favorite "'bubber' ducky". It "displaces" the water around it. We call that duck the Thaumaturgic Field. It’s everywhere. It permeates every atom, molecule, and soul. It’s carried by particles we call Thaumions - basically quantum middle fingers to the Standard Model. And trust me, they’re real. We’ve measured them. Every spell ripples through the Thaumaturgic Field like a fart in a wind tunnel - invisible to those without the "gift", but undeniably real. Thank the thaumions for that. Frosted steel bites. My wrists sing the bruise‑colored hymn they started rehearsing the moment the rune‑cuffs first locked, each note sharper than the last. A crimson‑armored Regulator nudges me forward with the flat of his warded baton. The corridor ahead is iced in thaumic blue, ceiling‑mounted auric strips thrumming like hive wings. The air tastes of antiseptic pine and latent ozone— the Academy’s signature perfume for don’t touch, don’t breathe, comply. I check the strip's pulse rate out of habit; 60Hz. Standard for containment, but the yellow undertone means the backup generators are cycling. Sloppy.Beneath the hum of the pumps, a speaker system plays a distorted, time-stretched loop of "Toxic" by Britney Spears, retuned to 432Hz for "maximum patient pacification." It’s working; a violent calm settles over me.I shuffle past a security panel, wincing as the decontamination mist hits the gash on my left eyebrow. Dried blood pulls tight—an ironic tilak, paired with the entropy‑scar constellations glowing a timid violet beneath my skin. Great. I probably look like a discounted saint in the clearance aisle. "Step," the Regulator drones, voice modulated through a brass half‑mask etched with anti‑contagion sigils. His partner raises a palm, rune‑plate flaring, and a transparent containment door iris‑spins open. Containment Ward 7‑C scrolls in holographic letters across the threshold. Underneath: BIO‑THAUM RISK: SEVERE.Intensive care for inconvenient miracles— that’s what 7‑C is. Where the Academy parks anything or anyone too magically radioactive to mingle with the donor‑banquet crowd upstairs. Today I’m the bleeding‑edge exhibit. My eyes half-close. If they want to treat me like a specimen, I might as well act like one.My boots squeak traitorously on the slippery disinfectant film. Above the ceiling tiles, mana-vacuum pumps whine at a pitch that rattles my teeth—a sub-audible drill into the skull. The air tastes of astringent ethanol layered over burnt rosemary, distinct as a chemical cocktail. Sterility flavored with failed ward incense. Everything is over-lit, over-white; even shadows look laundered here.A pair of articulated arms descend from the ceiling rig the moment I cross the gasket line. They’re chromed, jointed like praying mantis legs, and end in crystal‑studded rings that dilate to encircle my chest. Needle-thin runes of spell-light probe through skin, bone, soul. Focus. Detox first, existential crisis later.I keep my sarcasm on an external monologue setting— easier to file complaints with Reality when you narrate.A phosphorescent diagnostic rune scrolls above me, projecting vitals I don’t need to see: ENTROPY LOAD: 173 μE. A fresh jolt of anger flares at Hartnell’s lacquered indignation, at the Regulators’ lock‑step morality, at the elder board’s impending pageantry. My anger tastes of solder smoke and old pennies. "You can’t keep me caged forever," I mutter—to the walls, the wards, the memory of Dr. Lucien Hartnell’s immaculate sneer. "But you’ll try, won’t you? Gods forbid a kid keeps breathing without a signed requisition form." The room’s lights do not answer. They only flicker—once, like nervous laughter trapped in a filament. My perception shifts.It starts as the high‑frequency buzz of the suppression lattice but morphs—subtly, inexorably—into the whine of ventilators. I’m no longer pacing a holding cell; I’m back in St. Gabrielle’s Medical Wing, three years prior, fluorescent bulbs bleaching everything to corpse colors.Dad lies swaddled in thrumming machinery. An arcane respirator—part machine, part bound elementals—forces each rise and fall of his chest. Respiratory Failure Type IV. A cleric from the Academy briefed us on prognosis in the dulcet tones reserved for terminal cases: "Stable as long as the mana subsidy lasts." Translation: Stable until you can’t pay.Mom signed the release forms with shaking hands. Their ink smudged; her knuckles did the same. We spent nights counting medical crystals, recalculating how many cubic centimeters of regulated miracle we could afford.I remember kissing Dad’s forehead, tasting antiseptic and fear. I remember whispering a promise: I’ll learn, Dad. I’ll fix this.The memory fractures——reassembling into a bursar’s office lined with floating ledger‑orbs. Numbers scroll along their mirrored surfaces, each digit another centimeter of noose. Scholarships? Conditional. Loans? Predatory. My acceptance letter glowed like salvation until the addendum spelled out the price of each "authorized" miracle: Fifty‑two thousand credits per annum, reagent cost not included.Mom sold the house. The respirator bill swelled anyway. I deferred a semester, took two jobs—graveyard shifts at a mana refinery and midnight runs in a trauma clinic triage bay where license checks were more optional suggestion than rule. That’s where I learned to hack the Academy limiters—small tweaks at first, life or death tweaks eventually.Back in present, my pacing falters. A metallic tang pricks behind my teeth—anger, adrenaline, or just poor ventilation. Hard to tell.Condensation on the glass sharpens into an ICU window again, but this one belongs to Mom. Pneumonic Magic Burn—complication from a spell she cast to save a child trapped in a flood. Unauthorized thaumaturgy, no protective null field. She drowned from the inside while regulators filed negligence charges.I visited during the "family hours" they grant right before final collapse. Mom pressed a shaking finger to my chest. "Power is only sacred when it’s spent lifting another soul. So reach—any hour, any street—and take their weight, even if the world never thanks you. Let purpose pay the cost gratitude can’t. And when your own flame gutters, make sure the room is crowded with hearts you’ve carried. Don’t slip away lonely like your father and me." The monitor silenced before I could answer. The curtain between us and everything righteous fell.Back to the claustrophobic present.I stop pacing. I will not be her martyr. I’ve bled tuition, sweat, tears, and enough raw entropy to power a small city, but I will not be a footnote mislabeled reckless.I wipe away the hanging beads of condensation, clearing a narrow patch on the ward‑glass. My breath fogs it again, a fresh canvas. With the tip of my index, I draw—slow, deliberate lines: a downward hook, two crossing slashes, a spiral folding in on itself. It’s the entropy sigil they teach as cautionary lore in Intro to Magical Thermodynamics—the symbol you should never evoke without stabilizers, because it invites chaos to dinner and forgets to set the table.My finger glows faintly as I trace. The ward‑glass sizzles where skin meets silicate, but no alarms scream. The suppression lattice shivers, unsure whether to stop me—this gesture is too small, too symbolic to quantify as a violation.The spiral completes. A tremor ripples through my bones—like a tuning fork struck in the marrow. The sigil hums a note I feel more than hear, resonant with the latent violet flicker buried under my skin. It’s not magic, not exactly. It’s intention. Intent shapes resonance; resonance becomes potential. "There’s a cost for every miracle," I whisper, voice rasping the cell’s recycled air. "So charge me. I’m done bartering with innocent lives." I press my palm flat against the sigil. The cold eats through the calluses. Memory and present overlap until I’m holding my father’s hand, clutching my mother’s, stabilizing a dying stranger, all at once.A single tear escapes—annoyingly sentimental—but I don’t wipe it. It crawls to my jaw, drops, splashes on the rune‑scored floor. It hisses where it lands. The lattice dims fractionally; the system registers an anomaly but not enough to mobilize.I breathe, count to five, release.My life until tonight has been scaffolding—courses, clinical rotations, sanctioned mission trips to disaster zones where every act of compassion came with a compliance checklist. That scaffolding is ash now. What I did in the alley was the bare minimum of what a cleric should do, yet it shattered the facade. The board will brand me reckless. Hartnell will spin a narrative where his absence is procedural necessity and my intervention is criminal zealotry.Fine.I step back from the sigil. It glows faintly on the glass, pulsing with each heartbeat—mine, the girl’s, Mom’s, Dad’s—a little constellation of debts.In the distant corridor, a klaxon bleats: two throaty wails and a long drone. That’s the signal for transfer— they’re moving detainees to pre‑trial holding. My time in this box is up.I straighten. Shake the stiffness from my shoulders. The sigil fades—the condensation bead‑trails evaporating as if ashamed. But the imprint stays branded behind my eyelids.Eight paces to the door. I’m halfway across when the rune locks unseal with a percussive clack. The door slides, revealing two Regulators in muted crimson, their batons crackling with polite menace. "Rao, Bodhi. Transfer protocol," the taller one states, visor reflecting my ghost‑lit face. I nod, wrists offered. The cuffs are colder than before, or maybe I’ve just run out of body heat to lose.As they guide me into the corridor, I glance back. The humid patch on the window is gone. Only a faint outline—less visible than a fingerprint—remains where the entropy spiral once burned.But I know it’s there. Like a promise sworn in blood and cold flame.The Regulators march me toward an elevator caged in thaumic mesh. Beyond the grate, the shaft descends deeper—toward tribunal chambers, public scrutiny, and the choreography of institutional judgment. I roll my shoulders, composing arguments sharper than scalpels and jokes darker than the shaft’s abyss.Next stop: the Tribunal of Ivory Smiles. Let them bare their teeth. I’ve already tasted worse.

item.title: chapter-01-draft
item.description: Cracked linoleum slits my knees like spite. The kind of petty cut you don't notice until it's stinging through your trousers and the adrenaline backs off. My breath fogs against the kind of winter air that doesn't just invade but squats in corners like it's paying rent. This cheap community "alley"-clinic stinks of half-sterilized bandages, mana-rot, burnt hair, and the quiet panic that lingers when death overstays its welcome. Faintly, the sound of royalty-free "muzak" haunts its way through the air, the Infomercial on the waiting room TV turned up. The girl beneath me convulses again. "Shh… shh, hey. You’re okay. You’re not—" Her spine jerks, back arching like a snapped bowstring, mouth frothing in crescents of pink. Her ribs rattle like a bag of old dice under my hands. Blood where there shouldn't be blood, breath where there shouldn't be gaps. Every twitch is a clock tick closer to an obituary. She's losing air, time, and odds—all at once. And me? I'm gambling with Magic.She’s maybe fifteen. Just a kid. Poor thing couldn't even get herself through the door. Pulse in freefall. Every rune-monitor in this slapdash trauma bay screams in a different dialect. A salvaged electrocardiogram kit whines next to a busted cauldron half-full of thaumic coolant. Someone has duct-taped a sanctified camphor talisman to the ceiling. Another has scrawled "LOVE IS A MIRACLE" over it in marker. Yeah? Try billing that to the regulator council.I don't have time to guess how long she's been dying, or how poorly I set this place up, or why the universe keeps leaving corpses at my feet and asking for a receipt. She's here. I'm here. No one else is.I press my palms to her sternum. Cold skin. Too light. The bones feel like they belong to someone who never finished growing. "ThRun-kel Tuu Vaar'lenna" No Echo. No Decay. A pulse kicks from deep in my diaphragm as a Null Field snaps into existence. The air distorts, rippling outward like the heat shimmer on asphalt, then stills. Reality—mundane, lawful, sanitized physics—gets politely evicted. The field blooms. Spherical. Fragile. A dome of anti-reality laced with stolen spells and prayers I barely believe in. The "Old Speech" tends to have that kind of environmental impact, but I'm going for broke here. The standard Med Protocol Statis Field would not be able to handle the severity of her wounds, or the consequences if what I'm about to do is detected.The tattoos etched across my forearms—entropy wards carved in ink and nerve endings—ignite. Pale violet. Huh. That's new. Questions for later. "Shul'dara Vek Thae-lun" Burn the end into Birth I start the incantation. The real one. No Academy-template safezone spells. No healing-lite first-aid authorized by thaumaturgical ethics boards. This is real magic, raw and unlicensed, hates being bent into shape.Each word tears its way up my throat like barbed wire. The null field hums louder, resisting the feed. Magic floods my limbs, burning as it threads itself through my arms. Through scar tissue from doing this sort of thing once-too-often, and spent muscle from just having a day-and-a-half. I force it down, into my wrists, into my fingers.Her wound slowly start shuddering as they stitch themselves together, previously-spilled ichor tracing its way back inside it's host.Not fast enough. Not nearly fast enoughShe's drowning inside herself. Organ failure. Lungs filling. My field tenses. Feedback spirals along my spine. The limiter—every damn student has one, coded into our IDs, our aura signatures, even the cuffs of our coats—snaps back like a whip.I push harder, audibly snarling. Focus. I redirect flow from my shoulders into the small fractures in my hands. The scars glow brighter –faint, ethereal cracks leaking sickly magenta light. My nails crack from the pressure. "Come on," I mutter. "Come on, breathe." Another pulse. Runes etched into the null field flare too wide, too sharp. If anyone nearby has a regulator beacon tuned, they’ll feel that. Screw it. I keep going. "Vaelun" "Please." Not a spell. A plea.Her alveoli begin to reknit. Capillaries reroute. Blood reverses direction like I'm unwinding her death.Then—a single inhale. Wet, but real.She jerks. Once. Then goes limp.Still.Still.And then—A breath.Holy shit.She's alive.For a single heartbeat, the world holds.And then the null field screams.Every rune-lamp in the alley explodes in sequence. Light. Shatter. Feedback. The regulator beacon embedded in the mana flow pings out like a flare. I’d bet half my tuition credits someone three blocks away just felt that. The spell collapses inward, folding the null field like paper into itself. Entropy backlash punches through my arms, singeing nerve endings raw. The air smells of ozone, blood, and divine sarcasm.Sirens bloom on the horizon. Not the friendly kind.I’m running out of time. "Nihil sanctus. Resurgo." The final phrase stings my gums as I seal the spell. I play it safe, ending the Triplet with Latin for stability, even if leaning on mass-production spellwork tastes a bit wrong in my mouth. Internal lattice reweaves. Circulatory rhythm stabilizes. Her color improves.I wrap her in a silver-foil thermal, tucking the edges under her elbows. I reach into my coat, unhook the entropy-seal clasped to my wrist—my tracker, my confession, my crime—and place it beside her fingers.Footsteps thud. Not fast. Intentional. Crimson-armored Regulators appear at the alley mouth in a staggered diamond formation. Wands already drawn. Suppression wards vibrating across their forearms.Eight of them. Full complement. They were expecting worse. "Hands where we can see them!" I stay kneeling.I raise my hands.Magic still dances in my bones. My grip on it loosens as I let it go. "I was just practicing my thesis," I say. Helmet visors don’t crack smiles. Worth a shot. "Step away from the girl." "She’s stable. If you touch her before the field fully fades, she’ll spike and you’ll have killed her." They don’t care. Two step forward. "Uh-uh, fellas. Florence Nightingale's got that sweet chin music for you if you touch my patient". Knowing their attention needs to be kept on me, I lean back on my heels and sit myself on my rear, my legs splayed and oh-so-conveniently blocking their path to the teen. The two give a glance at one another, before rejoining the group to form a half-circle. One begins the arrest ritual, voice flat, like I’m just another datapoint. "Name. Student ID. Magical license class." I tilt my head. Real slow. Let the silence drag an extra beat. Then I twist my lips into the most exaggerated, cartoonishly unimpressed pout I can muster—upper lip out, nose crinkled, eyelids half-mast like I’ve just smelled bureaucratic rot baking in the sun. "No." I really let that syllable drag out. Not shouted. Not whispered. Just... stated. Like gravity. Or spite. I swear even their hoods looked shocked. "You refuse to comply?" "I'm declining to comply, Chief" I say, the vowels dripping with the sacred indignation of a Looney Tune on his last carrot. "Subtle difference." Somewhere in the back of my head, I hear a faint wahh-wahhhh fade in the distance. One of the Hoods with a Golden North Atlantic Magic Federation Insignia emblazoned on his right-arm gauntlet steps forward. I wonder if he can see my smirk behind that visor.A wand muzzle touches my temple. It hums. Yeah. He saw it. "Unauthorized miracle-working in a restricted zone." "Emergency clause." "No academy supervisor signed off." That’s it. That’s the moment.I throw my arms up in full-body disbelief, like I’m trying to scoop the sheer stupidity out of the air with my hands. "She was dying! That's what makes it an emergency, you phenomenal DUNCE!" My hands are flying. I’m gesturing like a man explaining fire to cavemen. One hand clutches at my own hair while the other points furiously at the void where this specimen’s common sense should be. I'm stunned—stunned—that this conversation is real.Then— "And you are not cleared to make that call!" He says it like it’s checkmate.I let out a laugh that’s more exhale than joy. Stare at him like I just caught a goose trying to recite algebra. "Oh, give your balls a tug!" I sneer, but internally I feel a bit of my fight deflate, my hands dropping to their side with it. Of course not. I'm not a licensed miracle-worker. Just a student. Just a cleric-in-training with a chip on his shoulder and a naive deathgrip on his remaining conscience.They slap the cuffs on. Cold metal laced with dampening sigils bites into the skin above my entropy scars. Numbness radiates. A sob tries to rise in my throat, but I’ve already learned how to kill those before they show.How do lawyers not break down in "Frustration TearsTM" when they're arguing in court?? Goddamn Sociopaths.I look down one last time. She’s breathing. God's above, she's actually still breathing. Sounds like a wet maraca, but it's there, and steady. Good. At least, way better than it was ten minutes ago.I exhale. The cuffs hiss. "Fuck magic." The shackles click shut.Let's talk about magic."The supernatural and mysterious power of apparently influencing a course of events." The ultimate cop-out for writers the world over. "Spooky action at a distance" if you're Einstein-inclined. Greeeeeeat. Those are the definitions you’d get if you asked a bored teenager who just binge-watched the entire Harry Potter franchise in one sitting. Magic, as mundanes tend to understand it, is basically a shortcut to doing stuff that would normally require effort, intelligence, or batteries. Which is hilarious, considering how much work it actually takes.I refuse to bother with a "real definition" for concept so nebulous. It's a wonder anyone can even pretend to define it. You already know what Magic is. Or at least, you think you do. Fireballs. Lightning. Glowy runes. Whatever. If it's shiny and not a mushroom, it's probably magic. How's that for a rigorous academic approach?But what's really going on behind the curtain of sparkles and special effects? What is Magic?I'll tell you. Magic is Some Ol' Bullshit.By and large, I'd say Harry Potter is to blame for people's preconceptions. Harry asks Hagrid why the magical world is secret and gets some spiel about how "aaaall the muggles" would want to start using magic to solve all of their problems.When the HELL has anything worked that way?Everything has a cost. Especially magic. And that cost is rarely financial. Though in modern society, magic tends to follow the same principle everything else does: "If you're good at it, never do it for free." If you want to get something, you have to give something up. And with Magic, you never quite get or give what you expected to.You know, while I'm on the topic, let's address the whole "muggle" and "mudblood" thing. NO ONE is investing time, effort, and energy on special slurs to call people based on magical lineage. Well…some people might but there are weirdos like that everywhere, we don't consider outliers. Trust me, we already have more than enough slurs… Case in point! My family is from India; I was raised as a citizen of the illustrious North Atlantic Magical Federation (a.k.a Woodbridge, New Jersey).The Federation has had access to the internet and cell phones as long as it's Mundane Counterpart; someone called me the "n-word" in traffic on Thursday. The Magical and Mundane peoples are just as advanced (and just as backwards) as one another. Humans are the same no matter where you go.We call that "progress".The wagon stinks of ozone, piss, and bureaucratic boredom. Chain-runes hiss every time I shift, crackling in some ancient dialect designed to shame sorcerers before laws even existed. They line the bars like barbed wire made of light, looping lazy helixes across the metal mesh of the cage. Cold bleeds through the floor, right into my spine. Every time the wagon hits a bump, the chain-loop under my seat flares a glyph in warning—reminding me that one twitch too far will sear through the skin.I sit cuffed, knees jammed against the slatted walls, ankles throbbing from where a dampening glyph kissed bone. The whole transport feels like an apology for compassion: cramped, loud, and rolling at a crawl down back alleys too narrow for emergency service but somehow wide enough to haul away unlicensed medics. The roof leaks condensation from spell-dampened air, and every drop that lands on me feels like the system spitting.Two Regulators sit opposite me, crimson armor gleaming like sin in the pulse-light. Helmets full-face, visors opaque. They haven’t spoken since they shoved me in the cage. Probably trained not to. If they said anything, it might sound like doubt. "You know," I say, loud enough to make their posture twitch, "in some countries, healing without a license is called 'heroism.'" No reply. Fine. I wasn’t really talking to them anyway. "Bet the girl makes it," I add, tone too casual to be anything but pointed. "Wouldn’t that be awkward? Alive and breathing and…not regulated, none of it." The one on the left tilts their helmet a hair. A shift smaller than a nod, but I clock it. Progress. Or maybe checking their rune-feed for violations of the local noise ordnance. "Just think," I continue, leaning back until the chain-runes tug sharp at my wrists, "if I'd let her die, none of this paperwork would be necessary. No reports. No tribunal. No sleepless nights wondering about all the regulations I broke and if they're thinking about you too." Still nothing. No verbal response, no twitch, no weight shift. But I catch the subtle tightening of a gauntlet, the telltale flutter of overclocked heart rate in the ambient hum of the suppression ward. The one on the right's pulse just spiked. Bingo. "All those Combat Magic courses they have you guys running must be winding you up too tight," I say, furrowing my brow in a performance of concern. "Must be hard, carrying all that armor and none of the moral weight. Heeeavy stuff, boys, heavy stuff." That gets a reaction. Barely. The right one's shoulders twitch like he wants to shrug off the insult and can't decide if that counts as breaking formation. "They must teach you all sorts of high-octane badassery, right? What is it these days? Arcane CQC? Wand-kata? Tactical Pilates? Wait wait, no I got it! Hot yoga!" I lean forward with a grin I know will get under his skin. "C'mon, big guy, what’s the secret sauce? Do you guys chant in unison, paint slogans on your chests before beating up street kids? Or is it more of a spontaneous thing?" The tension in the hothead's jaw is now a tectonic event. He hasn't moved, but the restraint in his posture is screaming. The kind of scream that comes right before a punch. "Okay," I say, like I'm offering a lifeline. "First answer that comes to mind: One hundred of your elite unit versus one silverback gorilla—who wins?" SLAM.The sound is a thunderclap. The impact knocks the air out of me before I process the pain. My head cracks against the steel mesh wall with a dull thud. Stars burst behind my eyes. Tinnitus screams in both ears. Copper floods my mouth.Hothead's up, gauntlet braced across my throat, the bulk of his armor pressing me into the van's reinforced wall like he's trying to meld me with it. "KEEP. YOUR MOUTH. SHUT" Each word is a hammer. Or maybe that was his fist. Each pause, a countdown. The kind of tone that tells you this isn't about me—not really. This is about something already cracked inside him and me showing him the fracture line.My chains rattle as I raise my hands a few inches, chuckling painfully—not in surrender, just enough to show I'm not going to fight him. Not yet.I lean my head back as far as the wall allows, staring up at the sigil-riddled ceiling. "Not trying to provoke you," I croak, voice hoarse with pressure and pride. "Well… not only. I'm just trying to fill the silence." Before it fills me first, the last part I leave unsaid.He holds there for a beat. Two. Breathing hard. The regulator's gauntlet trembles for half a second before he pushes off, steps back, and resumes his silent post like nothing happened. Like I imagined it. Like he's not one weak insult away from kicking my ribs in.I cough, blood in my teeth now, and smile like I’m proud of it. Because I am.Next checkpoint's close. I can feel it in the way the hum of the runes syncs with my heartbeat.Good. I’m starting to run out of things to say.The city outside blurs by. I try not to track it too closely. New Canaan's alleys all look the same when you're on your way to get publicly flogged by bureaucracy. But the moment we round a corner and the ward-glass clears, I get a clean look at the skyline. It hits like always: a punch to the throat made of glass and privilege.Above the slums: the sky-bridges. Floating over half-frozen gutters and blown-out wards, they gleam like myth. Suspended by ley-tethers and taxpayer arrogance, the Academy towers connect overhead like the bones of some divine spinal cord. Clinics up there don’t use salvaged glyph-lamps or bootleg entropy seals. They have name-brand miracles. Branded. Billable. One floor for necrotics. Two for the elite-class trauma ward. Three for the insurance-backed rebirth suites.A perfect place to get sick, if you can afford it.Below, the street-level looks like a field hospital designed by a committee of vultures. Blood-slick slush slops under our wheels. Half the rune tags on the buildings are faded, overwritten with gang sigils or protest glyphs. I spot one that says "HEAL US OR HAUNT US" in spray-rune. Can't tell if it's a threat or a prayer. Someone tagged a ward-drain with a stencil of the Angel of Entropy, wings half-melted. "Tell me," I ask the Regulators, "when you signed up to protect the magical public interest, was criminalizing CPR part of the recruitment poster?" Stone silence. They’ve either muted their helm-audio or filed me under ‘rhetorical hazard.’I shift again. Chain-runes bite my wrist like they resent my pulse. Probably do. These things were forged to bind deviance, not dialogue. Every move I make pings a silent report to the Academy’s Enforcement Matrix. I imagine some overworked functionary back at HQ scrolling through my vitals like a bored ex. "Ever wonder what a miracle's worth?" I murmur. "Not in credits. In consequence." Still nothing. Maybe they don't have clearance to talk about metaphysics. Maybe they just don't get paid enough.We roll to a stop.The gate checkpoint. Reinforced sigil-barrier, three layers deep, staffed by more crimson meat-suits holding arc-pikes like they were born gripping them. The wagon lurches as it docks into the intake platform. A dozen anti-teleport wards spark briefly as the runes verify we’re not smuggling eldritch contraband or curse-slugs. I sit very still, mostly to savor the irony. Once, this same checkpoint let me through with a lunchbox full of Class II healing runes and no questions asked.The lead tech – some poor bastard who looks about fifteen under their helm – waves a wand through the window slit. "Subject: Rao, Bodhi. Suspected Class IV unauthorized miracle-working. Confirmed thaumic residuals.En route to Academy Custody." One of the watchers glances at the readout. Her jaw tenses. "Cleric track?" "Fourth-Year," the other replies. "Shit." The sound is barely audible, but I catch it. She covers with protocol. "Proceed." The wagon rolls on.Through the next viewport I see a boy – maybe twelve – watching from behind a chain-fence, bundled in a coat five sizes too big. Her Brother I realize in recognition. I barely clocked the kid before, too preoccupied with saving the girl 's- his sister I remind myself -life. There is the faint recollection of him screaming bloody murder as I shunted him inside the clinic and set up my makeshift Trauma Bay in the alley. When our eyes meet, he makes the sign of healing. Not the Academy one. The old one. Fingers curled, thumb to sternum. Passed down by grandmothers who never made it past orientation exams. The kind of sign you learn when your miracles are all secondhand.I give him a wink and a quick smile; the boy was worried to bits about his older sister, no need to stress him out any further.The cage jolts as we pass under another suppression arch. Somewhere behind me, an etheric scanner starts logging my aura decay. It’ll show entropy scars flaring on contact with the girl. It won’t log the hesitation in my hands. The silent prayer. The look in her brother's face when she finally stopped seizing. The breath that wasn’t supposed to come back.None of that goes in the file. "You know what your problem is?" I say to the rune-bars. They don’t answer. "You're efficient. You're clean. You're quiet. You erase stories as well as scars." Still nothing.But the runes glow a little dimmer. Or maybe that's just me.Next stop: Containment Ward 7-C. Cold fire, automated scanners, and a medic who thinks I’m a contaminated tool.Can’t wait.

Any resemblance to actual persons, living, dead, or currently undergoing a messy "Sub-Resurrection Causal Inversion," is entirely coincidental. Don’t test the White Mage.Now, stop reading the fine print and get to the story. I’ve got a booboos to tend to.-- Bodhisunya "Bodhi" Rao(Unlicensed, Suspended, and Highly Irritated)
